questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female presented with Schizophrenia. Which of the following antipsychotic drug causes least weight gain? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ziprasidone

 

Ziprasidone is known to cause less weight gain compared to many other antipsychotics, making it a more suitable option for an obese patient concerned about further weight gain. Clozapine and olanzapine, in particular, are associated with a higher risk of significant weight gain and metabolic changes. Chlorpromazine, while potentially causing weight gain, is generally not as strongly linked to this side effect as clozapine or olanzapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorpromazine: This is a typical antipsychotic. These drugs can cause weight gain, though chlorpromazine is not as strongly associated with weight gain as some atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option B. Clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic known for causing significant weight gain, along with other metabolic effects.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another atypical antipsychotic that is frequently associated with substantial weight gain and metabolic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic associated with a lower risk of weight gain. It is considered more weight-neutral compared to other atypical antipsychotics like clozapine and olanzapine.

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic drug. It also produces sedation and adverse effects like dry mouth and hypotension. All these actions result due to action on which of the following receptors?(INICET MAY 2024)

 

1. D2 and 5HT2 receptors

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic receptors

3. Muscarinic and alpha-adrenergic receptors

4. H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Chlorpromazine is a typical anti-psychotic drug having main mechanism of antipsychotic action as D2 blockade and minor as 5 HT2 blockade. However, it also blocks many other receptors that can result in adverse effects.

 

While chlorpromazine does block H1 receptors causing sedation, it is not the sole receptor responsible for its adverse effects. It must be considered in conjunction with D2, 5HT2, muscarinic, and alpha-adrenergic receptors.

 

Other Option:

 

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic Receptors: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of anti-psychotic drugs

 

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/470-471

choices.text: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist
It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel
Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about prasugrel? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a pro-drug

 

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is metabolized by the liver to its active metabolite, which is an inhibitor of P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors. This active metabolite irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation, making prasugrel a potent antiplatelet agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist is incorrect because prasugrel is not a P2Y12 agonist but rather an inhibitor.

 

Option B It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel: It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel is incorrect because prasugrel is actually more potent than clopidogrel.

 

Option D. Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding: Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding is incorrect because omeprazole can interfere with the activation of prasugrel to its active metabolite, reducing its antiplatelet effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prasugrel is a pro-drug that, upon hepatic metabolism, becomes an active metabolite that irreversibly inhibits the P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors, thus preventing platelet aggregation and making it a potent antiplatelet agent.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaint of a jaw swelling. His tissue was found to have the presence of t (8;14). The histopathological appearance of the bone marrow aspirate tissue is given in the image. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkitt lymphoma 

 

The presence of a translocation t(8;14) is characteristic of Burkitt’s lymphoma. The same is confirmed by the tumor cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli.

 

Direct lines from Robbins.. - ”When the bone marrow is involved, aspirates reveal tumor cells with slightly clumped nuclear chromatin, two to five distinct nucleoli, and royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular lymphoma: Characterized by t(14;18) translocation and involves BCL2 gene, not typically presenting with jaw swelling.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Does not involve t(8;14) translocation and has different histopathological features.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Plasma cell neoplasm, typically presents with bone pain, anemia, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia, not with t(8;14) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt lymphoma is identified by the presence of the t(8;14) translocation and histopathological features including cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli. It commonly presents with jaw or abdominal tumors and requires prompt recognition and treatment due to its aggressive nature.

questions.text: A bank employee, felt depressed with no interest in activities, came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea, or excessive saliva production, is not a common side effect of SSRIs like escitalopram. It is more commonly associated with the atypical antipsychotic drug clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia, or difficulty achieving orgasm, is a well-known side effect of SSRIs due to their impact on serotonin levels, which can interfere with sexual function.

 

Option C. Nausea: Nausea is one of the most common side effects of SSRIs. It typically occurs at the beginning of treatment and may subside with continued use.

 

Option D. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams are another common side effect of SSRIs. They occur due to the influence of increased serotonin levels on sleep patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Escitalopram is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).
  • Other SSRIs include Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Fluvoxamine etc.
  • Side-effects of SSRI include:
  • Most common: Nausea, Vomiting
  • Next most common: Anxiety etc.
  • Other side effects- Delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, diarrhea, vivid dreams etc.
  • Main drug which causes sialorrhea is CLOZAPINE (an atypical anti-psychotic drug)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/488

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

  • Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). By inhibiting PCSK-9, evolocumab increases the number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors available on the surface of liver cells, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. It is used for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that works by reducing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. It is used to lower LDL cholesterol levels but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits angiopoietin-like protein 3 (ANGPTL3), which reduces levels of triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, and other lipids. It is used for treating homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor used primarily as an immunosuppressant in transplant patients and in certain types of cancer. It is not related to cholesterol metabolism and is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, evolocumab is the correct answer as it is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to lower LDL cholesterol levels.

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is contraindicated in iron poisoning? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BAL (British Anti-Lewisite)

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite), also known as dimercaprol, is contraindicated in cases of iron poisoning.

 

BAL should not be used in this case because it can form toxic complexes with iron, exacerbating the condition rather than alleviating it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EDTA: EDTA is a chelating agent used primarily for lead and other heavy metals, but it is not contraindicated in iron poisoning. However, it is not the preferred chelating agent for iron poisoning either.

 

Option C. DTPA: DTPA (Diethylenetriamine pentaacetic acid) is another chelating agent used for certain radioactive heavy metals and is not specifically contraindicated in iron poisoning, although it is not used for iron either.

 

Option D. Desferrioxamine: Desferrioxamine is the chelating agent of choice in iron poisoning. It binds to free iron and forms a complex that is excreted in the urine, making it effective in reducing iron levels in cases of acute iron toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) is contraindicated in Cadmium and Iron poisoning.

 

Desferrioxamine is the appropriate chelating agent to use in cases of iron poisoning.

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cat scratch disease

 

Stellate granuloma is seen in cat-scratch disease. It is also called as subacute regional lymphadenitis.

 

It is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella henselae. Acquired following contact with infected animals (commonly cats).

 

Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:

 

  • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
  • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
  • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells
  • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with cough, low-grade fever, and hemoptysis. Investigations reveal a cavitary lesion on her right lung apex, which on biopsy reveals caseous necrosis. The underlying pathophysiology is: (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction

 

The clinical scenario with complaints of cough, low-grade fever, hemoptysis is suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis. The diagnosis is further supported by a cavitary lesion in the apex of the lung and a biopsy showing caseous necrosis. The pathophysiology is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction mediated by activated macrophages.

 

Tuberculosis is a chronic pulmonary and systemic disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

With certain persistent or nondegradable antigens, such as tubercle bacilli colonizing the lungs or other tissues, the perivascular infiltrate is dominated by macrophages over a period of 2 or 3 weeks. The activated macrophages often undergo a morphologic transformation into epithelium-like cells and are then referred to as epithelioid cells. A microscopic aggregation of epithelioid cells, usually surrounded by a collar of lymphocytes, is referred to as a granuloma. This pattern of inflammation, called granulomatous inflammation, is typically associated with strong T-cell activation with cytokine production. It can also be caused by foreign bodies that activate macrophages without eliciting an adaptive immune response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enzyme degradation: This does occur in TB but is not the primary mechanism leading to the granulomatous response and caseous necrosis.

 

Option C. Fibrinoid deposition: This is typically associated with immune complex-mediated conditions, not TB.

 

Option D. Sudden cut-off of blood supply: This would more likely result in coagulative necrosis, not the caseous necrosis seen in TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary tuberculosis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with caseous necrosis, driven by a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction mediated by activated macrophages and T-helper cells.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 392

choices.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, direct Coombs test

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought with pallor and jaundice. On examination he had a hemoglobin of 9g/dl and mild splenomegaly. He has a history of similar episodes from birth.  The peripheral smear had red cells without central pallor. Which of the following is useful for making the diagnosis of the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility test 

 

Presence of mild jaundice, splenomegaly and anemia is suggestive of hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis. Since the history of similar episodes since child birth is present it is more likely a familiar case and so, the most appropriate answer is hereditary spherocytosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, direct Coombs test: While autoimmune hemolytic anemia also presents with hemolysis, the history of episodes from birth and the specific peripheral smear findings are more suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Typically presents with acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, not with a chronic history from birth.

 

Option D. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): Characterized by intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and a different set of laboratory findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis should be suspected in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and spherocytes on a peripheral smear. The osmotic fragility test is a key diagnostic tool for this condition.

 

  • Spherocytes are more fragile in hypotonic solutions due to reduced surface area-to-volume ratio.
  • Newer and more sensitive tests include EMA (Eosin-5-maleimide) binding test by flow cytometry.

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can be transmitted through various means, including sexual contact, from mother to child during childbirth, and through blood transfusions. Syphilis can be transmitted by all components of the blood, making it a comprehensive risk in blood transfusion contexts.

 

While other infections like hepatitis B and C, malaria, and HIV can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, the question specifically asks for an STD. Among the options given, syphilis is the only STD that fits this criterion.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: Incorrect because while hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through blood transfusions, they are not classified primarily as sexually transmitted diseases.

 

Option B. Filariasis: Incorrect because filariasis is a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, not through blood transfusions or as an STD.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect because malaria is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes and through blood transfusions, but it is not an STD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is an STD that can be transmitted by all components of the blood, highlighting the importance of thorough blood screening.

questions.text: Lignocaine is used in a loading dose for the treatment of arrhythmias. The loading dose of this drug depends upon which of the following factors? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Volume of distribution

 

The loading dose of a drug is calculated using the formula:

 

 

In the context of Lignocaine, which is administered intravenously (IV) for the treatment of arrhythmias, the bioavailability is 100% because the drug is delivered directly into the bloodstream. Therefore, bioavailability does not factor into the calculation when the drug is given IV. The critical factor influencing the loading dose in this scenario is the volume of distribution (Vd), which represents the extent to which the drug distributes into body tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clearance: Clearance relates to the maintenance dose rather than the loading dose. It reflects the body's efficiency in eliminating the drug.

 

Option C. Half-life: Half-life is important for determining dosing intervals and steady-state concentration but does not directly determine the loading dose.

 

Option D. Bioavailability: While bioavailability is included in the loading dose calculation, it is only a determining factor when the drug is not administered intravenously. In this case, where Lignocaine is given IV, bioavailability is 100% and thus does not influence the loading dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The volume of distribution is the key factor that determines the loading dose of a drug, especially in intravenous administration where bioavailability is 100%

questions.text: Heavy chain disease associated with the presence of kappa light chains in the urine: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

 

Explanation: 

 

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (also called lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma) is characterized by production of IgM monoclonal protein and is associated with the presence of kappa light chains. In this condition, light chain (kappa) is produced in the same quantity as heavy chain (mu), which contrasts with other heavy chain diseases where there is predominant production of heavy chain antibody. The disease presents as an M spike of IgM type and commonly manifests with hyper viscosity syndrome due to the large size of IgM molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mu chain disease - This is incorrect. Mu (μ) chain disease is a rare heavy chain disease associated with CLL rather than with the presence of kappa light chains in urine. It involves the production of abnormal μ heavy chains without associated light chains.

 

Option B. Sezary disease - This is incorrect. Sezary syndrome is not a heavy chain disease but a variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by erythroderma, lymphadenopathy, and neoplastic T cells (Sezary cells) with cerebriform nuclei in the blood.

 

Option C. Franklin disease - This is incorrect. Franklin disease (gamma heavy chain disease) is characterized by the production of gamma (γ) heavy chains without associated light chains. It presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, but not specifically with kappa light chains in urine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is distinguished from other heavy chain diseases by the production of intact IgM molecules with balanced synthesis of heavy and light chains (including kappa light chains), often leading to hyper viscosity syndrome due to high levels of the large IgM protein.

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient presented with a rectal mass 2.5 cm by 3 cm. On biopsy it had the presence of colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells.  Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartoma

 

The clinical history of a rectal mass on biopsy having the colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is suggestive of a juvenile polyp. This polyp is an example of a hamartomatous polyp.     

 

Hamartoma:

 

  • Definition: A hamartoma is a benign, focal malformation that resembles a neoplasm but grows at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. It is composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue elements that are normally found at that site.
  • Juvenile Polyp: A type of hamartomatous polyp commonly found in children. It is characterized by the presence of dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells, as described in the biopsy findings.
  • Clinical Presentation: Typically presents as a solitary rectal polyp in young children, often causing painless rectal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choristoma: A benign growth of normal tissue in an abnormal location, not consistent with the described biopsy findings.

 

Option C. Adenoma: A benign neoplasm of glandular tissue, typically presenting with dysplastic changes, not the dilated glands with mucin and inflammatory cells.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: A malignant tumor of glandular origin, which would show invasive growth and cellular atypia, not consistent with the benign nature of the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A rectal mass in a young child with biopsy findings of colonic mucosa and multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is indicative of a juvenile polyp, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. He has a retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise.  There is no mucosal bleeding in the patient. Which of the following coagulation factor can be responsible for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor 8/9 deficiency

 

The presence of recurrent deep tissue bleeding (retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise) in a male is suggestive of a clotting factor deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand factor deficiency: Typically presents with mucosal bleeding and prolonged bleeding time, not deep tissue bleeding as described.

 

Option C. Lupus anticoagulant: Usually associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to a paradoxical increase in thrombosis rather than bleeding.

 

Option D. Factor 9/12 deficiency: Factor XII deficiency does not cause significant bleeding and is usually discovered incidentally with prolonged aPTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia, caused by deficiencies in factors VIII or IX, presents with recurrent deep tissue bleeding and hemarthrosis, without significant mucosal bleeding. This differentiates it from other bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A vegan lady came with features of anemia. She is likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

Explanation:

 

Vegans, who follow a diet that excludes all animal products, are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is primarily found in animal-derived foods such as meat, dairy products, and eggs. Since vegans do not consume these foods, they are prone to developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D deficiency is not specifically related to a vegan diet. While vegans may need to supplement vitamin D from non-animal sources, the question does not provide enough information to suggest that this is the likely deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin A deficiency is also not directly related to a vegan diet. Vegans can obtain sufficient vitamin A from plant-based sources such as leafy green vegetables, carrots, and sweet potatoes.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency is unlikely in a vegan diet, as many fruits and vegetables are rich sources of vitamin C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vegans are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia, as vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal-derived foods.

questions.text: Isotype switching is seen in? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activated B cells  

 

Isotype switching is seen in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching: Conversion of one antibody class (isotype) to another resulting from the genetic rearrangement of heavy-chain constant-region genes in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching is dependent on the presence of both antigens and cytokines secreted by T-cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Helper T cells: While Helper T cells (especially Th2 cells) provide the necessary cytokines that drive isotype switching in B cells, they themselves do not undergo isotype switching.

 

Option C. Cytotoxic T cells: Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) are involved in killing infected or cancerous cells and do not produce antibodies or undergo isotype switching.

 

Option D. Naive B cells: Naive B cells, which have not yet encountered their specific antigen, initially produce IgM and IgD. They do not undergo isotype switching until after activation by an antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotype switching is a process that occurs in activated B cells, allowing them to produce different classes of antibodies to effectively combat various types of pathogens.

questions.text: A young boy recently visited a temple with his grandmother. Upon returning, he has been crying inconsolably, presenting with cold extremities and a blood pressure of 170/100 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate course of treatment for his condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prazosin

 

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of scorpion sting, characterized by symptoms of vasoconstriction like hypertension and cold extremities. Prazosin, an alpha-1 blocker is drug of choice for treatment of scorpion sting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation and suppresses the immune response. However, it is not typically used to manage scorpion stings, as it does not address the acute hypertensive crisis and autonomic storm caused by the sting.

 

Option C. Adrenaline: Adrenaline (epinephrine) is a catecholamine that increases heart rate and blood pressure. It would likely exacerbate the hypertension and vasoconstriction already present in the patient, making it an inappropriate treatment choice for scorpion sting.

 

Option D. Anti-snake venom: Anti-snake venom is used to neutralize the effects of snake bites. The symptoms described do not align with a snake bite but rather with a scorpion sting, making this treatment inappropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate treatment for a scorpion sting, which presents with severe pain, hypertension, and cold extremities, is prazosin. It effectively counters the effects of excessive catecholamine release by blocking alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, thereby reducing vasoconstriction and lowering blood pressure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to hospital with pain in great toe. His serum uric acid was raised. He was given a medication to relieve the pain and inflammation and after that, he was put on a drug for long term treatment of gout. Which of the following drug increases the excretion of uric acid in urine? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Probenecid

 

  • Probenecid increases the excretion of uric acid in urine by inhibiting the tubular reabsorption of uric acid. It is a uricosuric drug.

  • Examples of other uricosuric drugs are Sulfinpyrazone, Benzbromarone and Lesinurad.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colchicine: Colchicine is used primarily for the treatment of acute gout attacks. It works by inhibiting granulocyte migration and reducing inflammation, but it does not increase the excretion of uric acid.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid.

 

Option D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is also a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, similar to allopurinol. It reduces the production of uric acid by inhibiting xanthine oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Probenecid is a uricosuric drug that increases the excretion of uric acid in the urine by inhibiting its reabsorption in the renal tubules. This makes it effective for the long-term management of gout by lowering serum uric acid levels. Other drugs like colchicine, allopurinol, and febuxostat have different mechanisms of action and do not increase uric acid excretion in the urine.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presented in OPD with complaints of fever, night sweats, and weight loss for 2 months. On examination, lymphadenopathy was present. They were non-tender, rubbery in consistency, located in the supraclavicular and inguinal regions on both sides. Peripheral smear showed the presence of bi-nucleated cells. Which markers can be identified in this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. CD15
  2. CD30
  3. CD19
  4. CD3
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

Clinical history and the histopathological examination showing bi-nucleated cells, called Reed Sternberg cells points to a diagnosis of Hodgkins lymphoma. RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+.

 

Reed-Sternberg cells marker –

 

  • CDI5
  • CD30 (most sensitive)
  • PAX-5 (most SPECIFIC)

 

 

Reed Sternberg Cells are non-specific since it is seen in conditions like:

 

  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Non- Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Infection Mononucleosis
  • Sarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

CD19 (3) and CD3 (4): These markers are associated with B and T cells, respectively. CD19 is a B-cell marker, and CD3 is a T-cell marker. They are not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells characteristically express CD15 and CD30, making these markers essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old chronic smoker presented with complaints of weight loss and cough for more than 1 year. He also has hypercalcemia. His biopsy report revealed hyperchromatic atypical cells. Which of the following is the most likely cancer is this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell cancer

 

The presence of hyperchromatic atypical cells on biopsy with the given clinical history suggests a cancer. The history of chronic smoking with hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome is a finding of squamous cell cancer (SCC) of the lung.  Hence, the answer is option “b”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small cell cancer: Often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) and Cushing's syndrome, not typically hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Large cell neuroendocrine tumor: Less common, may have neuroendocrine features but not specifically associated with hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: More common in non-smokers and often presents with peripheral lung lesions. Not typically associated with hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is strongly associated with smoking and can present with hypercalcemia due to ectopic PTHrP production, alongside symptoms such as chronic cough and weight loss.

questions.text: A patient displaying lytic lesions on the skull is being considered for a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. What represents a distinctive discovery on electron microscopy among the following options? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

 

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histiocytes: While Langerhans cells are a type of histiocyte, the presence of histiocytes alone is not specific to LCH. The defining feature is the presence of Birbeck granules.

 

Option C. Eosinophils: Eosinophils are often present in LCH lesions, especially in eosinophilic granuloma, but they are not a distinctive finding on electron microscopy.

 

Option D. Giant cells: Giant cells may be present in a variety of inflammatory or granulomatous conditions, but they are not specific to LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a distinctive and pathognomonic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with ophthalmic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug used in combination with other medications to treat tuberculosis. One of its significant side effects is ophthalmic toxicity, specifically optic neuritis.

 

Ethambutol inhibits the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, which is necessary for the synthesis of the mycobacterial cell wall.

 

Ophthalmic Toxicity:

 

  • Optic Neuritis: Ethambutol can cause inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision problems.
  • Symptoms: Patients may experience blurred vision, loss of visual acuity, and difficulty distinguishing between red and green colors (red-green color blindness).
  • Monitoring: It is crucial to monitor visual acuity and color vision regularly in patients taking ethambutol. Any signs of visual impairment should prompt immediate cessation of the drug and consultation with an ophthalmologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is another first-line anti-tubercular drug. Its main side effects include hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy, but it is not commonly associated with ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Option C. Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used as a second-line treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). It is associated with ototoxicity (hearing loss) and nephrotoxicity, not ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Option D. Rifampin: Rifampin is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that can cause hepatotoxicity and discoloration of bodily fluids (e.g., urine, tears) to an orange-red color. It is not typically associated with ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is a first line anti tubercular drug that can cause optic neuritis and red green color blindness.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has malaise for 2 weeks. His investigations revealed an elevated creatinine of 4.5mg/dl. His blood tests also showed the presence of HBs antigen. A renal biopsy was performed which demonstrated spike and dome on special staining. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranous glomerulopathy

 

The elderly patient is having a renal dysfunction. The presence of a ‘spike and dome’ pattern on special staining (silver staining) is suggestive of immune complex deposition. This is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy. The diagnosis isd also supported by the presence of HBs antigen as the hepatitis B infection is characteristically associated with development of membranous glomerulopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: Typically presents with nephrotic syndrome in children and does not show the spike and dome pattern on biopsy. No change on light microscopy; Electron microscopy shows podocyte effacement

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli, not associated with the spike and dome pattern.

 

Option D. Renal amyloidosis: Demonstrates amyloid deposits that can be identified with Congo red staining and apple-green birefringence under polarized light, not a spike and dome pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous glomerulopathy, associated with hepatitis B infection, presents with nephrotic syndrome and demonstrates a characteristic spike and dome pattern on renal biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposits.

 

Histology: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Agranulocytosis.

 

Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine. Agranulocytosis is a condition characterized by a dangerously low level of neutrophils (a type of white blood cell) in the blood. Neutrophils are crucial for fighting infection, so their reduction significantly increases the risk of serious infections. Patients on clozapine are closely monitored with regular blood tests to detect this condition early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Akathisia: This is a condition characterized by a feeling of inner restlessness and an inability to stay still. It is a common side effect of typical antipsychotics but it is unlikely to be seen with clozapine.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: While antipsychotics can have sedating effects, respiratory depression is not commonly associated with clozapine.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: This is not typically associated with clozapine. Hyperthermia can occur with neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), a rare but serious side effect of typical antipsychotics in general. It is not associated with the use of clozapine.


Educational Objective:

 

Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine, requiring regular monitoring of white blood cell counts to ensure early detection and prevention of serious infections.

choices.text: It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors
It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect of tachycardia
It primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles
It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors

 

  • Labetalol is a 3rd generation beta blocker having the property of additional α and β blockade.

  • α1 receptor blockade leads to the relaxation of arterial smooth muscle and leads to vasodilation, The beta 1 blockade also contributes to a fall in blood pressure as it blocks reflex sympathetic stimulation of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect of tachycardia: Is direct acting vasodilators like hydralazine and minoxidil.

 

Option C. It primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles: Could be nitrates because they cause primarily venodilation.

 

Option D It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth muscle: Is the property of vasodilators.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 5-year-old child is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

  • The history and the provided imaging, which shows a single punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim and with a beveled edge look, point to Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).
  • LCH is a rare disorder involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, abnormal cells deriving from bone marrow and capable of migrating from skin to lymph nodes. This condition particularly affects children and can present with single or multiple lytic bone lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma:  A diagnosis of multiple myeloma is made by the typical triad of symptoms, which includes a marrow plasmacytosis of more than 10%, radiologic evidence of lytic bone lesions, and the presence of serum and/or urine M component.

 

 

Option C. Metastasis: In children, metastatic lesions in the skull are uncommon and typically originate from primary neuroblastoma or sarcoma but would present with different clinical features and possibly multiple lesions.


Option D. Primary hyperparathyroidism:  Patients with this condition have high levels of the parathyroid hormone, as well as hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis is the most probable diagnosis given the age of the child, the radiographic appearance of the skull lesion, and the absence of systemic symptoms or biochemical abnormalities typically associated with the other conditions listed.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors work by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. This increased urinary glucose can create an environment that promotes the growth of bacteria, thereby increasing the risk of urinary tract infections. This class of drugs is well known for its association with UTIs and genital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It works by increasing incretin levels, which in turn increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon secretion. Sitagliptin is not commonly associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea and abdominal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

choices.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.text: Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA helicase

 

Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to a defect in DNA helicase.

 

This rare genetic disorder is characterized by premature aging, with patients typically experiencing symptoms associated with aging at an accelerated rate. The defective gene product in Werner syndrome is a DNA helicase, a protein that plays a key role in DNA replication and repair by unwinding the double helix structure of DNA.

 

 

A defect in this enzyme leads to the rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage, which can mimic the cellular aging process. This chromosomal damage is believed to contribute to the Clinical features of Werner syndrome, such as premature graying and hair loss, thinning and wrinkling of the skin and hyperpigmentation, cataracts, osteoporosis, Short Stature, Metabolic Abnormalities and an increased risk of cancer.

 

The diagnosis of Werner syndrome is typically based on clinical features, family history, and genetic testing. There is no cure for Werner syndrome, and treatment is primarily supportive and focused on managing symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased telomerase activity: Increased telomerase activity typically prevents telomere shortening, which is not associated with the premature aging seen in Werner syndrome.

 

Option C. Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity: Decreased telomerase activity leads to shortened telomeres, not an increase in length. However, telomere lengthening is not a feature of Werner syndrome.

 

Option D. Reduced free radicals: Reduced free radicals would theoretically reduce oxidative damage and potentially slow aging. This is not related to the premature aging observed in Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Premature aging in Werner syndrome is primarily due to a defect in DNA helicase, leading to rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage and the manifestation of aging-related symptoms at an accelerated rate.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a previous history of GTCS presents with convulsions which are ongoing since 45 minutes. What should be the appropriate management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam.

 

In the case of a prolonged seizure such as status epilepticus, immediate seizure termination is critical. Lorazepam is a preferred initial treatment due to its rapid onset of action in stopping seizures. After the acute phase is managed, levetiracetam can be used for ongoing seizure control. This combination makes option (a) the most appropriate choice for the described scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate followed by Gabapentin: Valproate is an effective antiepileptic drug, but it's not typically the first choice for acute seizure termination in the emergency setting of status epilepticus. Gabapentin is used as a maintenance therapy for seizures but not in the acute setting.

 

Option C. Ethosuximide followed by Gabapentin: Ethosuximide is used primarily for absence seizures and is not appropriate in the acute management of status epilepticus. Gabapentin, as mentioned, is for maintenance therapy.

 

Option D. Carbamazepine followed by Gabapentin: Carbamazepine is used for the treatment of epilepsy but is not the drug of choice in the acute management of status epilepticus. Gabapentin, again, is for longer-term control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is one of the first-line treatments for the acute management of seizures, particularly in status epilepticus. Following the control of immediate seizures with lorazepam, levetiracetam can be used as maintenance antiepileptic therapy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal. No immature cells. A lymph node biopsy was performed which shows diffuse effacement of the Lymph node architecture, cells with an indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus, and are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

The clinical scenario presented here, which includes fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 positive BCL2 positive cells, strongly suggests follicular lymphoma.

 

The most common type of indolent NHL is follicular lymphoma. It usually appears in middle age and affects both men and women equally. The tumour is most likely caused by germinal centre B cells.

 

A (14;18) translocation between the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18 is the hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Histologically, at low magnification, a predominantly nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes. Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions: (1) small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small cleaved cells); and (2) larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts.

 

Immunophenotyping - The neoplastic cells closely resemble normal germinal center B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface Ig, and BCL6. CD5 is not expressed. BCL2 is expressed in more than 90% of cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt Lymphoma: Typically presents with a high-grade lymphoma and a starry sky pattern on histology. It is associated with c-MYC translocation and does not usually express BCL2.

 

Option C. Mycosis Fungoides: A type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that presents with skin lesions and does not typically show CD10 or BCL2 positivity.

 

Option D. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML): Characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene) and presents with marked leukocytosis and often splenomegaly, not with lymphadenopathy and histological findings as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is characterized by diffuse effacement of lymph node architecture, cells with indented nuclei and prominent nucleoli, and positive immunophenotyping for CD10 and BCL2. It typically presents in middle-aged individuals with symptoms such as fatigue, tiredness, and lymphadenopathy. The presence of the t(14;18) translocation involving BCL2 is a hallmark of this indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

choices.text: Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure
High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces increase in blood pressure and heart rate
A patient pre-treated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline
Increase in blood pressure is produced by intravenous propranolol

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of Dale? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A patient pre-treated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline

 

Vasomotor Reversal of Dale:

 

Adrenaline stimulates both α1 and β2 receptors. The α1 receptors have very strong vasoconstrictor property whereas the β2 receptors are very sensitive receptors and they cause vasodilation. Since the α1 receptors are stronger, on administration of adrenaline, they are stimulated leading to vasoconstriction. After some time, metabolism takes place and only β2 is stimulated which causes low blood pressure. This phase does not also last for a long time as metabolism happens and brings back the blood pressure to the normal level. This is the biphasic response of adrenaline (two phases in which BP increases in the first phase and decreases in the second).

 

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha blocker. So if adrenaline is administered along with it , then the alpha receptor stimulation will not happen , and there will be only stimulation of the β2 receptors leading to vasodilation and severe hypotension. This phenomenon of a patient pretreated with phentolamine developing severe hypotension on the administration of adrenaline is known as the vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure: This describes tachyphylaxis, which is a rapid decrease in response to a drug after repeated doses, not vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Option B. High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces an increase in blood pressure and heart rate: This describes the pharmacological effects of acetylcholine and atropine but is unrelated to vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Option D. Increase in blood pressure is produced by intravenous propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta blocker that usually causes a decrease in blood pressure by blocking β1 and β2 receptors, leading to reduced cardiac output and vasodilation. This statement is incorrect and unrelated to vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of Dale occurs when a patient pre-treated with an alpha blocker like phentolamine experiences severe hypotension upon administration of adrenaline due to the unopposed stimulation of β2 receptors, leading to vasodilation instead of the usual vasoconstriction and pressor effect.

questions.text: Most important enzyme in acute inflammation during respiratory burst is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

 

The respiratory burst is a crucial process in the immune response where neutrophils rapidly increase their oxygen consumption to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill invading pathogens. The key enzyme that initiates this process is NADPH oxidase (aka Respiratory burst oxidase enzyme). NADPH oxidase catalyzes the conversion of oxygen (O₂) into superoxide anions (O₂⁻), which are then further converted into more reactive species like hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and hypochlorous acid (HOCl-) via other enzymes like myeloperoxidase (MPO). These reactive species are potent antimicrobial agents, essential for destroying bacteria and fungi during acute inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MPO (Myeloperoxidase): While MPO is important in the conversion of hydrogen peroxide into hypochlorous acid (a powerful microbicidal agent), it acts downstream of NADPH oxidase. Thus, it is not the primary enzyme initiating the respiratory burst.

 

Option C. Defensin: Defensins are antimicrobial peptides that kill bacteria particularly against mycobacterium tuberculosis, by disrupting their cell membranes. They do not play a direct role in the respiratory burst or the generation of ROS.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, acting as an antioxidant to protect cells from oxidative damage. It does not contribute to the generation of ROS in the respiratory burst and is involved in mitigating the effects of ROS rather than promoting their formation.

 

Also, Catalase activity is used as a diagnostic tool to differentiate between types of bacteria. For example, the presence of catalase is used to distinguish catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus (staph) from catalase-negative organisms like Streptococcus (strep).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH oxidase is the most important enzyme in the process of respiratory burst during acute inflammation. It initiates the production of reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for the immune system's ability to kill pathogens.

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

 

The anti-apoptotic factor among the following is BcI-2.

 

Apoptosis is a process of programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms. It is a highly regulated process that involves a complex network of proteins and signaling pathways. Among the proteins involved in apoptosis are two families of proteins known as the Bcl-2 family and the caspase family.

 

The Bcl-2 family of proteins includes both pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members. The pro-apoptotic members include Bax, Bak, and others, while the anti-apoptotic members include Bcl-2, Bcl-XL, and others. The balance between pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family is important in determining whether a cell will undergo apoptosis or not.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P-53: P-53 is a tumor suppressor protein known for its role in preventing cancer. It can induce apoptosis but is generally considered a promoter of cell cycle arrest and DNA repair in response to DNA damage, rather than being anti-apoptotic.

 

Option B. K-ras: K-ras is an oncogene that, when mutated, contributes to cancer progression by promoting cellular proliferation and survival, not directly inhibiting apoptosis.

 

Option D. BAK: BAK, like Bax, is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family. It promotes apoptosis by facilitating mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, which is a critical step in the activation of the apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.

questions.text: A middle aged female presents with headache. Radiological examination reveals a 2 cm mass attached to the dura. Which of the following will most likely be observed on histopathology? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Psammoma Bodies with Whirling

 

  • Psammoma bodies with whirling are particularly associated with certain tumors, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma, meningioma (a type of brain tumor that often arises from the dura), and serous ovarian tumors.
  • The presence of psammoma bodies with a characteristic whirling appearance in the histopathological examination of the mass attached to the dura would strongly suggest a meningioma as the likely diagnosis.
  • It is benign tumor, arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is the loss of chromosome 22q

 

 

  • Psammoma bodies are concentric calcific structures.
  • They appear as round, laminated calcifications under the microscope. The presence of psammoma bodies in a tumor can provide important diagnostic clues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fried Egg Appearance: This appearance is typically associated with oligodendrogliomas, not meningiomas.

 

Option B. Antony A and B Areas: These areas are characteristic of schwannomas.

 

Option C. Verrucae Bodies: These bodies are not related to meningiomas or the described clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psammoma bodies with a whirling appearance are characteristic of meningiomas, a type of brain tumor that often arises from the dura.

questions.text: Which of the following feature is correct on the basis of given karyotype? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gynecomastia and long limbs

 

Given karyotyping image shows '47, XXY' abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter's syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flat occiput: This feature is typically seen in Down syndrome (Trisomy 21).

 

Option C. Webbing of neck and lymphedema: These are characteristic features of Turner syndrome (45, X).

 

Option D. Short stature and polydactyly: These are features seen in Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is characterized by gynecomastia, long limbs, small testes, and infertility.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 316-317

choices.text: It is approved for treatment of absent seizures
Fine tremors can be noted within therapeutic range

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding lithium is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fine tremors can be noted within therapeutic range

 

Lithium is a commonly used medication for the treatment of bipolar disorder, but it can cause fine tremors within the therapeutic range. The tremors are generally mild and not a significant side effect for most patients, but in some cases, they can be bothersome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is approved for treatment of absent seizures: This is incorrect. Lithium is not used for the treatment of absent seizures. It is primarily used in the management of bipolar disorder and sometimes for treatment-resistant depression.

 

Option C. It does not cause teratogenicity: This is incorrect. Lithium can cause teratogenic effects, particularly if used during the first trimester of pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of cardiac anomalies, such as Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Option D. It is not absorbed orally: This is incorrect. Lithium is well absorbed orally and reaches peak plasma concentrations within a few hours of ingestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium, a medication commonly used for bipolar disorder, can cause fine tremors within the therapeutic range. It is well absorbed orally and has teratogenic potential, making it important to use with caution in pregnant women.

questions.text: All are reduced in Iron Deficiency Anemia except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TIBC

 

In Iron Deficiency Anemia, Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) is increased in order to compensate to the deficient state.

 

Iron deficiency anemia –

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin: Ferritin is an intracellular protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion. In IDA, ferritin levels drop as iron stores are exhausted.

 

Option C. Iron: Serum Iron reflects the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. In IDA, serum iron levels are reduced because iron stores are depleted.

 

Option D. Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin that is saturated with iron. In IDA, it is reduced because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DDs of microcytic anemia:-

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1231-1234

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a bone marrow aspirate having the finding as shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase defect

 

The image shows a Gaucher cell, which is characterized by its large size, crumpled tissue paper-like cytoplasm, and abnormal lysosomal accumulation.

 

Gaucher cells are seen in Gaucher's disease, which is the most common lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme defect leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within the cells, resulting in the characteristic appearance seen in bone marrow aspirates.

 

Gaucher's disease presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and hematologic abnormalities due to the accumulation of these lipid-laden cells in the bone marrow, liver, and spleen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphingomyelinase defect: This enzyme defect is seen in Niemann-Pick disease, not Gaucher's disease. Niemann-Pick cells are large foamy cells filled with sphingomyelin and cholesterol, which have a distinctly different appearance compared to Gaucher cells.

 

Option C. Galactosidase defect: This refers to a deficiency in alpha-galactosidase A, which is associated with Fabry's disease, a lysosomal storage disorder that affects the skin, kidneys, heart, and nervous system, but does not produce Gaucher cells.

 

Option D. Hexosaminidase defect: A deficiency in hexosaminidase A is the cause of Tay-Sachs disease, which is characterized by a cherry-red spot on the retina and severe neurological impairment, without the presence of Gaucher cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher's disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder, caused by a glucocerebrosidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of Gaucher cells with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper-like appearance in bone marrow aspirates.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has experienced the loss of her newborn. She is currently producing breast milk, leading to discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent this complication? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the goal is to prevent lactation to avoid discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. The appropriate treatment involves using a drug that can suppress prolactin secretion, as prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion, effectively suppressing lactation. It is often used for this purpose and can be an effective choice in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an antiprogestin used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a direct role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that can increase prolactin levels, which would not be helpful in this context.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent and antiemetic that also increases prolactin levels, making it unsuitable for suppressing lactation.

 

Given these options, the correct choice for preventing lactation and thus avoiding the associated complications is: b. Cabergoline

questions.text: A young female, who did not disclose her pre-existing history of asthma, presented to a hospital for the treatment of gout. She was given aspirin, after which an acute asthma attack was precipitated. What is the likely cause of bronchoconstriction in this patient? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Augmentation of LOX pathway

 

The likely cause of bronchoconstriction in this patient is the augmentation of the LOX (lipoxygenase) pathway. Aspirin and other NSAIDs can cause bronchoconstriction in susceptible individuals by inhibiting the COX (cyclooxygenase) pathway. This shifts the arachidonic acid metabolism towards the LOX pathway, increasing the production of leukotrienes, potent bronchoconstrictors, which can precipitate asthma attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blockade of COX pathway: While aspirin does block the COX pathway, the bronchoconstriction is more directly related to the subsequent augmentation of the LOX pathway.

 

Option B. PG mediated bronchoconstriction: Prostaglandins generally have a bronchodilatory effect, so their inhibition by aspirin is not the primary cause of bronchoconstriction in this context.

 

Option D. Release of histamine: Histamine release is not the primary mechanism of aspirin-induced asthma, though it may play a role in allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin-induced bronchoconstriction in patients with asthma is primarily due to the augmentation of the LOX pathway, leading to increased production of leukotrienes, which are potent bronchoconstrictors.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia presented to the hospital, his BP is 88/68 mm Hg, Serum K+ is 6 mEq/L, serum sodium is 120 mEq/L. Patient was started on intravenous fluids. What additional specific therapy will you add?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydrocortisone

 

The presentation of an 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension (BP is 88/68 mm Hg, which is low for this age), hyperkalemia (serum K of 6 mEq/L), and hyponatremia (serum sodium of 120 mEq/L) is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This is a common form of CAH and can lead to a decrease in cortisol and aldosterone production, with an accompanying increase in adrenal androgens.

 

Given this clinical picture, the specific therapy to be added would include:

 

  1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: This is critical to suppress the overproduction of adrenal androgens. Hydrocortisone is commonly used, especially in pediatric patients, due to its short duration of action and lower impact on growth.

  2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone is usually added to manage the aldosterone deficiency, which is contributing to the hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.

  3. Sodium Chloride Supplements: In some cases, especially in infants and young children, additional sodium chloride supplements may be necessary to manage hyponatremia.

  4. Monitoring and Adjustment: Regular monitoring of electrolytes, blood pressure, and growth is necessary to adjust therapy accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Potassium Binding Resins: While these can be used to treat hyperkalemia, they do not address the underlying cause of the electrolyte imbalance in this scenario, which is likely due to aldosterone deficiency. Therefore, it would not be the first choice.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This is used primarily for heart failure and certain arrhythmias, not for the conditions described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Calcium Gluconate: This is used in the acute management of severe hyperkalemia to stabilize cardiac membranes. While it might be used in an emergency setting for life-threatening hyperkalemia, it does not address the underlying cause in this case and is not a long-term management strategy.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone (option a), as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone, as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/314

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothelial injury

 

Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.

 

Thrombosis is the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, obstructing the flow of blood through the circulatory system.

 


 

Three primary abnormalities, known as the Virchow triad, are known to cause thrombosis.

 

They include:

 

  • Endothelial injury - most important factor
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet activation: While platelet activation is a crucial step in the formation of a thrombus, it is typically initiated by endothelial injury, making endothelial injury the primary initiating event.

 

Option C. Coagulation cascade: The coagulation cascade is activated following endothelial injury and platelet activation, but it is not the initiating event of thrombosis.

 

Option D. Vasoconstriction of vessels: Vasoconstriction occurs as a response to endothelial injury and helps limit blood flow to the site of injury, but it is not the initiating factor in thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombosis is primarily initiated by endothelial injury, which is a key component of the Virchow triad and leads to the subsequent activation of platelets and the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Which is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium valproate

 

Sodium valproate is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea. It's an anticonvulsant medication that has proven effective in managing the involuntary movements associated with this condition. It works primarily by enhancing the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, which helps reduce abnormal electrical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a medication used primarily to treat gout by reducing the levels of uric acid in the blood. It is not used for the treatment of rheumatic chorea.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, and seizures. While it can provide muscle relaxation and sedation, it is not the drug of choice for managing refractory rheumatic chorea.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that can be used in some movement disorders. While it has been used in chorea, it is not considered the optimal treatment for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its side effect profile and efficacy compared to sodium valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium valproate is the preferred drug for treating refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its efficacy in reducing involuntary movements by enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain. It has a better side effect profile for long-term management of this condition compared to other options.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of chronic stable angina is seen in the outpatient department. She is already taking aspirin and statins, but continues to experience occasional chest pain during exertion. Which of the following would be the most appropriate choice for prophylactic treatment of her angina? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral nitroglycerine

 

Oral nitroglycerine is the most appropriate choice for the prophylactic treatment of chronic stable angina in this patient. Long-acting nitrate preparations, like oral nitroglycerine, are used to prevent angina episodes rather than for immediate relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sublingual nitroglycerine: This is used for rapid relief during an acute angina attack, not as a prophylactic treatment.

 

Option B. Intravenous nitroglycerine: This form is typically used in acute care settings, such as for unstable angina or during a myocardial infarction, not for routine prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Intratracheal nitroglycerine: This is not a recognized route of administration for nitroglycerine in the treatment of angina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral nitroglycerine, a long-acting nitrate preparation, is the most appropriate choice for the prophylactic treatment of chronic stable angina to prevent angina episodes during exertion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hemostatic agent? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Boric acid

 

Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. Boric acid is commonly used as an antiseptic, insecticide, and in various industrial applications, but it does not possess properties that would promote blood coagulation or control bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zeolite and Option D. Kaolin are microporous aluminosilicate minerals with large surface areas, having high hygroscopicity and excellent hemostatic performance. Zeolite absorbs blood and the releases Ca2+ into the blood and to activate the intrinsic path of coagulation cascade.

 

Option B. Chitosan: Chitosan is a biopolymer derived from chitin, which is found in the shells of crustaceans. Chitosan and its derivatives are known to accelerate the hemostasis process by promoting platelet adhesion and activation. This helps in forming a stable clot more quickly, which is particularly useful in controlling external bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. Hemostatic agents like Zeolite, Chitosan, and Kaolin work by activating the coagulation pathways to control bleeding.

questions.text: A patient presented with tingling and numbness in the legs, polyuria, and weight loss. He underwent a bone marrow aspirate (image as shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma with renal involvement

 

The bone marrow aspirate image shows numerous plasma cells with eccentric nuclei, which is a hallmark of multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow.

 

Patients often present with symptoms such as polyuria, weight loss, and neuropathy due to the disease's impact on the kidneys and bones. The presence of more than 10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, renal involvement is common in multiple myeloma due to the deposition of monoclonal light chains, contributing to the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  SACD due to diabetes: Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) in the context of diabetes would involve neuropathy, but it would not lead to the significant increase in plasma cells seen on the bone marrow aspirate. Bone marrow biopsy is not typically indicated in diabetic neuropathy.

 

Option B. SACD with B12 deficiency: This condition leads to neurological symptoms like tingling and numbness but usually presents with megaloblastic anemia rather than increased plasma cells. It does not explain the bone marrow findings or the systemic symptoms of polyuria and weight loss.

 

Option D. Metastasis: Metastatic disease can affect the bone marrow but would not typically present with a significant number of plasma cells with eccentric nuclei as seen in multiple myeloma. Additionally, the systemic symptoms and bone marrow findings align more closely with multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is identified by an increase in clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, accompanied by systemic symptoms such as renal involvement, neuropathy, and weight loss.

questions.text: All of the following are the part of the innate immunity except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B lymphocytes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha defensins: These are antimicrobial peptides that are part of the innate immune system. They are produced by neutrophils and epithelial cells and help to protect against a wide range of pathogens.

 

Option C. Gamma Delta T lymphocytes: These are a subset of T cells that participate in both the innate and adaptive immune responses. They are considered part of the innate immune system due to their ability to respond quickly and non-specifically to a wide range of pathogens.

 

Option D. Lectin pathway: The lectin pathway is one of the pathways that activate the complement system, a key component of innate immunity. It is initiated by the binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to pathogen surfaces.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A young female presented with flank pain, smoky urine and edema. Her urine examination revealed the presence of 20 RBCs/HPF with dysmorphic red cells. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

The presence of dysmorphic red cells in the urine and smoky-colored urine indicates glomerular hematuria, which is characteristic of glomerulonephritis. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a common cause of glomerulonephritis, especially in children and young adults. It typically follows a streptococcal infection (such as pharyngitis or impetigo) by 1-3 weeks and presents with symptoms like hematuria, edema, and hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrolithiasis: Kidney stones usually cause hematuria with non-dysmorphic red cells and flank pain but not typically associated with smoky urine or dysmorphic RBCs.

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: This condition can cause proteinuria and hematuria but is less likely to present acutely with the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: This condition primarily causes nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria and edema but not usually hematuria with dysmorphic red cells.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Presence of dysmorphic red cells and smoky urine is suggestive of glomerulonephritis. Out of the given options, post streptococcal glomerulonephritis is the most important condition associated with glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C3b

 

C3b functions as an opsonin.

 

Opsonization: - The process of coating a foreign particle and preparing it for phagocytosis. The substances involved in this process are called opsonins.

 

Include:

 

  • Mannose-binding lectin
  • IgM and Fc receptor of IgG
  • CRP
  • Fibrinogen
  • C3b, C4b, C5b

 

Other Options:
