Options A. C3a and C. C5a: These are anaphylatoxins involved in inflammation and promoting chemotaxis.

 

Option D. C6: Part of the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C3b is an opsonin important in the immune system for marking pathogens for phagocytosis, enhancing the body's ability to clear infections.

choices.text: It is an Equal Mixture of Local Anesthetics
It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine in a ratio of 50 percent each
Excessive use can result in methemoglobinemia
5 ml of 5 percent mixture contains 50 mg lignocaine

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the patch used in the given figure is correct? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Excessive use can result in methemoglobinemia

 

The patch in the image is an EMLA patch, which stands for Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics. It is commonly used to numb the skin before procedures like needle insertions. The EMLA patch contains a mixture of two local anesthetics: lignocaine (also known as lidocaine) and prilocaine, each at a concentration of 2.5%.

 

One of the known side effects of prilocaine, especially when used in excessive amounts, is the risk of methemoglobinemia. This condition occurs when hemoglobin is converted to methemoglobin, which cannot effectively release oxygen to body tissues. Although the risk is generally low, it can be significant in infants and other at-risk populations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is an Equal Mixture of Local Anesthetics: This statement is misleading. While the mixture contains equal concentrations of lignocaine and prilocaine (2.5% each), the term "eutectic" is key, indicating that the two anesthetics lower each other's melting points when combined, creating a mixture that is liquid at room temperature. The emphasis should be on the "eutectic" nature rather than just being an "equal mixture."

 

Option B. It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine in a ratio of 50 percent each: This is incorrect because the EMLA patch contains lignocaine and prilocaine, not ropivacaine.

 

Option D. 5 ml of 5 percent mixture contains 50 mg lignocaine: This calculation is incorrect. A 5% solution means 5 g of the drug is present in 100 ml of solution, which translates to 50 mg/ml. Therefore, 5 ml of the mixture would contain 250 mg of lignocaine, not 50 mg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prilocaine, one of the components of the EMLA patch, can cause methemoglobinemia, especially when used in excessive amounts or in vulnerable populations like infants.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not increase the risk of bleeding in patients undergoing warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Carbamazepine

 

Warfarin is an anticoagulant that is metabolized primarily by the CYP2C9 enzyme. The risk of bleeding with warfarin therapy is influenced by drugs that either inhibit or induce the metabolism of warfarin.

 

Carbamazepine, is an enzyme inducer. It induces CYP450 enzymes, including CYP2C9, which increases the metabolism of warfarin, leading to reduced plasma warfarin levels and a decreased anticoagulant effect. Therefore, carbamazepine does not increase the risk of bleeding; instead, it can reduce the effectiveness of warfarin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cimetidine: Cimetidine is a known inhibitor of the CYP450 enzymes, including CYP2C9. By inhibiting this enzyme, cimetidine reduces the metabolism of warfarin, leading to higher plasma concentrations of warfarin and an increased risk of bleeding.

 

Option C. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is an inhibitor of several CYP450 enzymes, including CYP2C9. This inhibition can lead to decreased metabolism of warfarin, increased plasma warfarin levels, and a higher risk of bleeding.

 

Option D. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is a potent inhibitor of CYP2C9. It reduces the metabolism of warfarin, resulting in elevated levels of warfarin in the blood and an increased risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs like Cimetidine, Isoniazid, Amiodarone, Clopidogrel, Ketoconazole, Verapamil etc inhibit the enzyme, thus reducing the metabolism of warfarin. This increases the plasma concentration of Warfarin and leads to increased risk of bleeding.

 

Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer and increases the metabolism of warfarin leading to decrease in effect of warfarin.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male presented with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following anti-diabetic drug acts by causing glucosuria? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin, as an SGLT2 inhibitor, is the drug among the options provided that acts specifically by causing glucosuria. This mechanism is unique to SGLT2 inhibitors and is a direct way of lowering blood glucose levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus. The other drugs listed work through different mechanisms that do not involve the induction of glucosuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarbose: This drug is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It works by slowing down the digestion of carbohydrates in the intestine, thereby reducing the rise in blood glucose after meals. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Option B. Glipizide: Glipizide is a sulfonylurea. It works by stimulating insulin release from the pancreatic beta cells. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor. It works by increasing the levels of incretin hormones, which increase insulin release and decrease glucagon release in a glucose-dependent manner. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 (Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter-2) inhibitor, works by blocking glucose reabsorption in the kidney, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine, i.e., glucosuria.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in acute mountain sickness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acetazolamide

 

Acetazolamide is the drug of choice for acute mountain sickness. Rapid ascent to high altitudes can lead to the development of headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, breathlessness etc. The underlying cause that has been implicated in its causation is cerebral edema. The low PO2 at high altitude causes arteriolar dilation, and if cerebral autoregulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favors increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue leading to cerebral edema.

 

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that leads to metabolic acidosis, which in turn stimulates hyperventilation, leading to CO2 washout, and it helps in reducing the formation of CSF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid and can be used as a treatment for cerebral edema and severe cases of AMS. However, it is not the first-line drug of choice for general AMS prevention or mild cases.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used primarily for heart conditions such as atrial fibrillation and heart failure. It has no role in the prevention or treatment of acute mountain sickness.

 

Option C. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used for treating hypertension and angina. It is not used in the management of acute mountain sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetazolamide is the drug of choice for acute mountain sickness because it induces metabolic acidosis and stimulates hyperventilation, helping to improve oxygenation and reduce cerebral edema.

questions.text: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute respiratory infection

 

Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Kartagener syndrome and C. Situs inversus: Kartagener syndrome also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia syndrome is due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of:

 

  • Sinusitis
  • Situs inversus - Major visceral organs are reversed or mirrored from their normal positions
  • Bronchiectasis

 

Infertility is also seen in Kartagener syndrome but it is not a part of its triad.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.

 

NOTE: Kartagener syndrome and cystic fibrosis are two different genetic disorders that can affect fertility in different ways.

 

  • In men with Kartagener syndrome, the cilia in the sperm cells may be abnormal or immotile, which can result in reduced sperm count and motility, leading to male infertility. Women with Kartagener syndrome may have reduced fertility due to impaired ciliary function in the fallopian tubes, which can lead to difficulty in egg transport and fertilization.
  • In the reproductive system, CF can cause thick, sticky mucus to block the vas deferens in men, leading to infertility due to the absence of sperm in the ejaculate. Women with CF may have reduced fertility due to thick cervical mucus that can impede sperm transport or block the fallopian tubes, preventing fertilization.

 

Overall, both Kartagener syndrome and cystic fibrosis can lead to infertility, but the underlying mechanisms and specific impacts on fertility can differ between the two conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliocytophthoria, the degeneration of ciliated cells, is typically seen in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1292

questions.text: A physician wanted to perform plasma glucose estimation using the vacutainer shown in the image. Which of the following is the anticoagulant used for this test? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Potassium oxalate

 

  • Potassium oxalate is commonly used in vacutainers for plasma glucose estimation because it acts as both an anticoagulant and it prevents clotting by binding calcium in the blood. We presume that the examiner by mistake showed the blue topped vacutainer in place of the gray one. However let us review that blue-topped vacutainer contains Trisodium citrate while the gray-topped vacutainer contains Potassium oxalate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisodium Citrate: Used primarily as an anticoagulant in blood collection tubes for coagulation studies, not suitable for glucose estimation because it does not prevent glycolysis effectively.

 

Option C. Sodium fluoride: Also a glycolysis inhibitor and commonly used with an anticoagulant (potassium oxalate) in glucose testing..

 

Option D. EDTA: Mainly used as an anticoagulant in hematology tests. While it effectively prevents blood clots, it does not inhibit glycolysis, making it unsuitable for glucose tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For accurate plasma glucose estimation, potassium oxalate and enolase is used because it effectively prevents blood clotting and preserves glucose by inhibiting glycolysis respectively. 

 

Always use a grey-top tube (NaF/KOx) when measuring plasma glucose to prevent post-collection glycolysis and falsely low results.

questions.text: Which site is most commonly used for the initial biopsy to confirm a diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Abdominal fat

 

Explanation: 

 

Abdominal fat aspiration is commonly used as an initial biopsy site to diagnose systemic amyloidosis. The procedure is minimally invasive with low complication rates compared to other tissue biopsies. Examination of abdominal fat aspirates stained with Congo red can be used for the diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis. While the test is quite specific, its sensitivity is lower than more invasive biopsies, but it is still preferred as an initial diagnostic approach due to its safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingiva - While gingival biopsy can be used to diagnose amyloidosis, it is not typically the first-line approach. Gingival tissue is a possible site for biopsy in patients suspected of having systemic amyloidosis, but it is less commonly used than abdominal fat aspiration.

 

Option B. Kidney - Kidney biopsy is performed when there are renal manifestations of amyloidosis but is not used as the initial diagnostic procedure due to its invasive nature and potential complications. It is usually reserved for cases where kidney involvement is the primary concern or when less invasive methods are inconclusive.

 

Option C. Rectal mucosa - Rectal mucosa biopsy can be used to diagnose systemic amyloidosis, but like gingival biopsy, it is not the first-line approach. It is more invasive than abdominal fat aspiration but may be performed when other sites yield inconclusive results.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abdominal fat aspiration is the preferred initial diagnostic procedure for systemic amyloidosis due to its minimal invasiveness, relative safety, and good specificity, although other tissue sites including kidney, rectal mucosa, and gingiva may be biopsied depending on clinical presentation and when fat aspiration is inconclusive.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male arrives at the emergency department with symptoms indicative of an acute ischemic stroke. It is decided to administer recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA), with a total dose of 80 mg. How much should be given as the initial bolus dose? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8 mg

 

For the administration of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) in acute ischemic stroke, the initial bolus dose should be 10% of the total dose. Therefore, for a total dose of 80 mg, the initial bolus dose should be 8 mg (which is 10% of 80 mg).

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering rtPA for acute ischemic stroke, the initial bolus dose should be 10% of the total dose. For an 80 mg total dose, the initial bolus is 8 mg, followed by an infusion of the remaining dose over 60 minutes.

questions.text: Apixaban belongs to which of the following class of drugs? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor Xa inhibitor

 

Apixaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. Other examples of this class of drug includes Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban.

 

It is the DOC for the treatment and prophylaxis of DVT, also for prophylaxis of thrombosis in monovalvular atrial fibrillation (except for severe mitral stenosis where Warfarin is used).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antifibrinolytic: Antifibrinolytics, such as tranexamic acid, work by inhibiting the breakdown of fibrin, stabilizing clots. Apixaban does not belong to this class.

 

Option C. Oral direct thrombin inhibitor: Oral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as dabigatran, directly inhibit thrombin (Factor IIa). Apixaban does not inhibit thrombin directly; it inhibits Factor Xa.

 

Option D. Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor: Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as argatroban and bivalirudin, are administered intravenously and inhibit thrombin directly. Apixaban is not administered parenterally and does not directly inhibit thrombin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apixaban is an oral direct Factor Xa inhibitor used for the prevention and treatment of thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and thromboembolism in nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic liver disease is experiencing recurrent urinary tract infections. His healthcare team is considering various antibiotics, including fluoroquinolones, to treat the infection. Which of the following fluoroquinolones is not recommended for use in patients with liver disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pefloxacin

 

  • Pefloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that is primarily eliminated by the liver. In patients with liver disease, pefloxacin can accumulate in the body and cause hepatotoxicity. Therefore, it is not recommended for use in patients with liver disease or hepatic impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that is eliminated by both the liver and the kidneys. It can be used with caution in patients with liver disease, provided the dosage is adjusted according to hepatic function.

 

Option B. Levofloxacin: Levofloxacin is another fluoroquinolone that is eliminated by both the liver and kidneys. It is generally considered safe for use in patients with liver disease, with appropriate dose adjustments based on hepatic function.

 

Option D. Lomefloxacin: Lomefloxacin is also eliminated by both the liver and kidneys and can be used in patients with liver disease, provided that dosage adjustments are made.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones that are safe in renal failure, avoided in liver failure and not effective in UTI include:

 

  • P: Pefloxacin
  • M: Moxifloxacin
  • T: Trovafloxacin
